results.title: Blood sweat and tears. Vol. 1
results.creator_credit: Frank Seres and Frank Seres Productions
results.brief_description: Narrated by Chris Haywood, this first volume of the “Blood sweat and tears” series contains the following episodes: “Obsession” looks at the seemingly obsessive attention given to sport by both the Australian media and the general public: investigates the questions why are there are sometimes when you can’t get anything on television except sport? and why do most people believe Donald Bradman is the most famous Australian of all time? “Winners and losers” shows the fine line that exists between success and failure in the ruthless world of international sport. “Black diamonds” looks at the issues surrounding Aboriginal achievements in sport. “Kill the bastards” looks at why people immerse themselves in a wider Self - a crowd of supporters, joined at the heart, not the head, bound by the team colours - to whom the one thing that gives life meaning is belonging, even if it means defeat.

results.title: Blood stock
results.creator_credit: Darrel Catling and J. Arthur Rank Organisation
results.brief_description: Beginning with all the gaiety of Epsom Downs on a traditional Derby Day, the film traces the career of a prospective Derby candidate, showing the generations of scientific breeding and the years of careful grooming and training which produce winners of this classic race. Shows famous studs, the yearling sales at Newmarket and the stables of well-known trainers.

results.title: Blood simple
results.creator_credit: Joel Coen, Ethan Coen and River Road Productions
results.brief_description: This stylish, low-budget, neo-noir thriller was the Coen brothers compelling debut feature and one of the most successful American independent features ever made. In the heart of Texas, a seedy private detective is asked by a spurned bar owner to murder his wife and her boyfriend. Having collected his fee, the private eye decides to make some variations to the murder contract. At this point the plot contorts into a blackly comic, serpentine web of misunderstandings, betrayals and counter betrayals where greed and fear trap the characters in a bloody nightmare of escalating terror. Arguably the most influential take on film noir since ‘Chinatown’, ‘Blood Simple’ established the Coen brother’s trademark style—engaging narrative, inventive direction, offbeat humour and the juxtaposition of grim violence with moments of sublime, sometimes surreal, human behavior. Barry Sonnenfeld’s innovatiove cinematography, (also seen in the Coens’ later films ‘Rasing Arizona’ and ‘Miller’s Crossing’) adds to this distinctive mix.

results.title: Blood on the wattle
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Hypothetical (Television Program)”.
Focuses on the importance and relevance of the Australian Constitution to its citizens. Apart from looking at its origins, and other constitutional models, this kit explores the implications of making changes to the Australian Constitution. Based on one of “Geoffrey Robertson’s Hypotheticals” entitled “Blood on the wattle”. Also includes a post-hypothetical discussion of the Constitution by the panellists.

results.title: Blood of Dracula
results.creator_credit: Herbert L. Strock, Herman Cohen and American International Pictures (AIP)
results.brief_description: Six weeks after her mother dies, Nancy Perkin’s father remarries, and she is reluctantly sent off to boarding school. There she falls under the evil spell of a teacher, who hypnotises her, converting Nancy to vampirism! In the third instalment of his horror trilogy (that includes “I was a teenage werewolf” and “I was a teenage Frankenstein” both 1957), producer Herman Cohen continues to trade on the themes of teen disenchantment and conflict between the rock and roll generation and their square parents. There is even a proto-feminist theme in this film, borne out by the ambitious teacher who seeks to prove herself in a man’s world. Predictably she meets a sticky end, not only as the villain of the piece, but also perhaps as a warning to meddlesome females.

results.title: Blood of a poet = Le Sang d'un poete
results.brief_description: This film depicts the metaphorical adventures of a poet and is composed of four episodes: “The Wounded hand or the scars of the poet”; “Do walls have ears”; “The Snow ball fight”; “The Profanation of the host”. The movie has an avant-garde roughness and unpredictability in its construction and use ofsymbols, but it is fundamentally a very characteristic, neo-Romantic study of the joy and agonies of being an artist. It remains extremely interesting and a source of Cocteau’s later work. In French dialogue only - no English subtitles.

results.title: Blood oath = Prisoners of the sun [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Stephen Wallace, Brian A. Williams, Denis Whitburn, Charles Waterstreet and Siege Productions
results.brief_description: The Ambon tribunal which tried 91 Japanese soldiers for war crimes against Australian prisoners during World War II provided the basis for the script co-written by the son of John Williams who was the Australian prosecuting officer (Captain Cooper in the film, played by Bryan Brown). The film attempts to portray the perplexing issue of war guilt, against the background of international power politics, through the rhetoric of courtroom drama. It can usefully be compared with the Japanese documentary “The Tokyo Trial” (1984), the second half of which deals with the trial of 28 alleged war criminals. Cast also includes George Takei, Terry O’Quinn, John Bach, John Polson, Russell Crowe, Toshi Shioya, John Clarke and Deborah Unger. In English and Japanese with English subtitles.

results.title: Blood money
results.creator_credit: Chris Fitchett, Chris Oliver and Tom Broadbridge
results.brief_description: Tense thriller starring Bryan Brown and John Flaus. Pete, a professional criminal who is dying of cancer, returns to Melbourne to settle a few scores. He wants to meet up with his ex-girlfriend and effect a reconciliation before facing death. The crime story is presented entirely from the criminal’s perspective. Rated: M

results.title: Blood is life
results.creator_credit: Great Britain. Ministry of Health and Basic Films
results.brief_description: Illustrates the work of Britain’s National Blood Transfusion Service. Shows how highly-trained personnel safeguard the health of donors and patients, by scrupulous care of equipment and checking of records. Describes the care with which blood is classified and stored, and how it finally reaches the patient in the operating theatre.
